body: Sounds like a reasonable feature to me. I think that we could close links after a much shorter period of inactivity (e.g. 1h) because if the devices of the affected tenant send messages at such a low rate then it probably doesn't hurt much if the downstream link gets established for each individual message.

I am also fine with one hour inactivity period. I had only in mind (I don't know if I remember correctly and if it is still the case) that messages to protocol adapters without pre-established links often fail with no credit issues.

That is indeed an issue. We might be able to address this with a well-chosen *flow latency* on the protocol adapters. However, if multiple devices of the same tenant start to send a message almost at the same time, then only the first message will be sent over the newly established downstream link whereas messages that have been uploaded afterwards, while the link is not established yet, will get the dreaded 503 ...
Maybe that is some configuration value that should be specified on a "per-tenant" basis. As this could be lower for your "test tenants" and higher for normal tenants.

I do not quite see how it is related to the tenant. The time it takes to receive the first credits depends on the AMQP Messaging Network peer that the adapter is connected to and the network latency between them. But at the time the sender link is established, there is nothing tenant specific happening FMPOV.

No, what I meant was the initial time of inactivity before the link gets closed. Instead of using 1 hour or 1 day, this could be configured for the tenant.

As my understanding is, that tenants get created for testing only. And those tenants could actually have a pretty short inactivity timeout (1 minute). While normal tenants could actually have a day (or some other system wide default).

issue.title: Remove metrics for no longer active tenants from Prometheus response

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Issues that we would welcome any help from (new) contributors with

issue.body:
Hi,

we've just started to use the new metrics based on Prometheus in Eclipse Hono. Very nice work!
However, one question has come to our attention regarding the amount of responded DataPoints of protocol adapters: 
In the Prometheus response I could observe two groups of data points: 
a) "Static data points" which are always there, e.g. with information of the jvm (for example: ``jvm_buffer_memory_used_bytes``)
b) "Dynamic data points" labeled with a certain ``tenant``. E.g.: ``hono_messages_received_seconds_max{component_name="hono-http",component_type="adapter",host="hono-adapter-http-vertx-7cd64d4867-c8p9s",qos="1",status="forwarded",tenant="acme",type="event",} 0.0``

The amount of returned DataPoints in the b) case grows with the amount of tenants which where at one point interacting with the protocol adapter. 

From the observations I made it looks like when a tenant stops interacting with the protocol adapter its metrics will still be returned in future. This leads to an over time growing amount of returned data points. This is inconvenient as it results in high load on the metric infrastructure and thus to high costs. Some cloud providers charge you based on the amount of points reported per scrape.

It would be nice that metrics for no longer interacting (e.g. by a specified time frame) tenants are removed from the result. 

What are your options? 

Thanks 
Chris

issue.title: [#1188] Close inactive downstream sender links.
issue.body:
There are a number of options where this feature (#1188) can be implemented and this is just a draft to discuss the general direction. As I am new to the Hono client code I would love to get some feedback.

When a downstream link is opened by a protocol adapter a timer is started that closes this link after a certain time. Each time the a message is sent on this link the timer is restarted. The time duration is configured in the `ProtocolAdapterProperties` section (e.g. "hono.mqtt.inactiveLinkTimeout") and defaults to 1 hour.

I tried to accomplish two things here:

1. be specific for downstream sender links (instead of a generic solution for all sender links)
2. be specific for protocol adapters regarding the configuration (instead of adding it to the very generic `ClientConfigProperties`). 

The result is FMPOV not really elegant, which is mainly because the downstream connection is mostly configured with `ClientConfigProperties` (in "hono.messaging"). 
Another point is that even though the class `AbstractDownstreamSender` sounds like a perfect candidate for the functionality, it's sub-classes need to be changed as well because they add custom send methods.
